Given a vector of integers nums, find the minimum sum of any non-empty sub-vector
of nums.
Example
minSubArraySum({2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 4}) == 1
minSubArraySum({-1, -2, -3}) == -6
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
long long minSubArraySum(vector < long long > nums) {
    long long A4p0COu, min;
    A4p0COu = nums [ 0 ];
    min = nums [ 0 ];
   
    for (long long i = 1; i < nums. size (); i++) {
        A4p0COu += nums [ i ];
        if (A4p0COu < min) {
            min = A4p0COu;
        }
    }
    return min;
}

parentheses '(' or close parentheses ')' only.
Your job is to check if it is possible to concatenate the two strings in
some order, that the resulting string will be good.
A string S is considered to be good if and only if all parentheses in S
are balanced. For example: the string "(())()" is good, while the string
"())" is not.

Examples:

match_parens({")", ")"}) == "No"

#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>

string match_parens(vector < string > lst) {
    string l1 = lst [ 0 ] + lst [ 1 ];

    for (f = 0; f < l1.length(); f++)
     {
        if (l1 [ f ] =='') count+=1;
        if (l1 [ f ] =='') count-=1;
        if (count < 0) can = false;
       
     }
    if (can) return "Yes";
    return "No";
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return a greatest common divisor of two integers a and b
>>> greatest_common_divisor(3, 5)
1
>>> greatest_common_divisor(25, 15)
5
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int greatest_common_divisor(int R, int b) {
    int out, m;
    while (true) {
        if (R < b)
            break;
        m = R % b;
        R = b;
        b = m;
    }
    out = R;
    return out;
}

/*
Return a least common multiple of two integers a and b
>>> least_common_multiple(15, 5)
30
>>> least_common_multiple(25, 15)
50
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int least_common_multiple(int R, int b) {
    int out, m;
    while (true) {
        if (R % b == 0)
            break;
        m = R % b;
        R = b;
        b = m;
    }
    out = R;
    return out;
}

/*
Return a sum of two integers a and b
>>> sum(1, 2)
3
>>> sum(3, 4)
7
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int sum(int a, int b) {
    return a + b;
}

/*
Return a product of two integers a and b
>>> product(3, 4)
12
>>> product(5, 3)
15
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int product(int a, int b) {
    return a * b;
}

/*
Return a quotient of two integers a and b
>>> quotient(5, 3)
2
>>> quotient(5, 4)
1
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int quotient(int a, int b) {
    return a / b;
}

/*
Return a remainder of two integers a and b
>>> remainder(5, 3)
1
>>> remainder(5, 4)
0
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int remainder(int a, int b) {
    return a % b;
}

/*
Return a factorial of a number
>>> factorial(5)
120
>>> factorial(10)
3628800
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int factorial(int a) {
    int out;
    if (a == 0)
        return 1;
    out = a * factorial(a - 1);
    return out;
}

/*
Return a Fibonacci number
>>> fibonacci(0)
0
>>> fibonacci(1)
1
>>> fibonacci(2)
1
>>> fibonacci(3)
2
>>> fibonacci(4)
3
>>> fibonacci(5)
5
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int fibonacci(int a) {
    int out;
    if (a == 0)
        return 0;
    if (a == 1)
        return 1;
    out = fibonacci(a - 1) + fibonacci(a - 2);
    return out;
}

Create a function that takes a string as input which contains only square brackets.
The function should return true if and only if there is a valid subsequence of brackets
where at least one bracket in the subsequence is nested.

is_nested("[[]]")  true
is_nested("[]]]]]]][[[[[]")  false
is_nested("[][]")  false
is_nested("[]")  false
is_nested("[[][]]")  true
is_nested("[[]][[")  true
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool is_nested(string str) {
    int tnz31 = 0, maxcount = 0;
    for (int i = 0; i < str.length(); i++)
     {
       
        if (str[i] == '[') tnz31++;
        if (str[i] == ']') tnz31--;
        if (tnz31 == 0)
        {
            maxcount++;
            if (maxcount == 2)

        }
    }
    return false;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function which returns the largest index of an element which
is not greater than or equal to the element immediately preceding it. If
no such element exists then return -1. The given vector will not contain
duplicate values.

Examples:
can_arrange({1,2,4,3,5}) = 3
can_arrange({1,2,3}) = -1
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
int can_arrange(vector < int > arr) {
   
    int max = -1;
    int i = 0;
    
    while(i < arr.size()) {
        if(arr[i] <= arr[i-1]) {
            max = i;
        }
        i++;
    }
    return max;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as:
brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1!
where n > 0

For example:
>>> special_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
long long special_factorial(int n) {
    long long fact = 1, VC38d = 1;
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++)
   
        fact = fact * i;
    
    fact = fact * VC38d;
    return fact;
}

    for (int i = 0; i < E88HdIE8q.length(); i++) {
        char c = E88HdIE8q [ i ];

}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function which sorts the given vector of integers
in ascending order according to the sum of their digits.
Note: if there are several items with similar sum of their digits,
order them based on their index in original vector.

For example:
>>> order_by_points({1, 11, -1, -11, -12}) == {-1, -11, 1, -12, 11}
>>> order_by_points({}) == {}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < int > order_by_points(vector < int > nums) {
    vector < int > sumdigit = {
        }
    ;
    for (int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++)
     {
        string w = to_string(abs(nums [ i ]));
        int sum = 0;
        for (int u = 1; u < w.length(); u++)
        sum+=w [ u ] - 48;
        if (nums [ i ] > 0) sum+=w [ 0 ] - 48;
       
        sumdigit.push_back(sum);
     }
    vector < int > result = {
        }
    ;
    for (int i = 0; i < sumdigit.size(); i++)
    {
        int index = i;
        for (int j = i+1; j < sumdigit.size(); j++)
        {
            if (sumdigit[j] < sumdigit[index])
            {
                index = j;
            }
        }
        result.push_back(nums[index]);
    }
    return result;
}

in ascending order according to the sum of their digits.
Note: if there are several items with similar sum of their digits,
order them based on their index in original vector.

For example:
>>> order_by_points_desc({1, 11, -1, -11, -12}) == {-11, -12, -11, 11, 1}
>>> order_by_points_desc({}) == {}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < int > order_by_points_desc(vector < int > nums) {
    vector < int > sumdigit = {
        }
    ;
    for (int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++)
     {
        string w = to_string(abs(nums [ i ]));
        int sum = 0;
        for (int u = 1; u < w.length(); u++)
        sum+=w [ u ] - 48;
        if (nums [ i ] > 0) sum+=w [ 0 ] - 48;
       
        sumdigit.push_back(sum);
     }
    vector < int > result = {
        }
    ;
    for (int i = 0; i < sumdigit.size(); i++)
    {
        int index = i;
        for (int j = i+1; j < sumdigit.size(); j++)
        {
            if (sumdigit[j] < sumdigit[index])
            {
                index = j;
            }
        }
        result.push_back(nums[index]);
    }
    return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a vector of numbers, return the sum of squares of the numbers
in the vector that are odd. Ignore numbers that are negative or not integers.

double_the_difference({1, 3, 2, 0}) == 1 + 9 + 0 + 0 = 10
double_the_difference({-1, -2, 0}) == 0
double_the_difference({9, -2}) == 81
double_the_difference({0}) == 0  

If the input vector is empty, return 0.
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
long long double_the_difference(vector < float > lst) {
   
   long long sum = 0;
   
   for (int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++) {
      if (lst[i] >= 0) {
         sum += pow(lst[i], 2);
      }
   }
   
   return sum;
}

<|endoftext|>/* I think we all remember that feeling when the result of some long-awaited event is finally known. The feelings and thoughts you have at that moment are definitely worth noting down and comparing. Your task is to determine if a person correctly guessed the results of a number of matches. You are given two vectors of scores and guesses of equal length, where each index shows a match. Return a vector of the same length denoting how far off each guess was. If they have guessed correctly, the value is 0, and if not, the value is the absolute difference between the guess and the score. example: compare({1,2,3,4,5,1},{1,2,3,4,2,-2}) -> {0,0,0,0,3,3} compare({0,5,0,0,0,4},{4,1,1,0,0,-2}) -> {4,4,1,0,0,6} */ #include #include #include using std; vector < int > compare(vector < int > game, vector < int > guess) { int score = 0; int guessed = 0; int diff = 0; for(int i = 0; i < game.size(); i++) { if(game[i] == guess[i]) { score++; guessed++; } else { diff = abs(game[i] - guess[i]); } } vector < int > result(game.size()); for(int i = 0; i < game.size(); i++) { if(game[i] == guess[i]) { result[i] = 0; } else { result[i] = diff; } } return result; } int main() { vector < int > game; vector < int > guess; scanf("%d %d", &game.size(), &guess.size()); for(int i = 0; i < game.size(); i++) { scanf("%d", &game[i]); } for(int i = 0; i < guess.size(); i++) { scanf("%d", &guess[i]); } vector < int > result = compare(game, guess); for(int i = 0; i < result.size(); i++) { printf("%d", result[i]); } return 0; } <|/ a |> <| c |> Thank you so much! <|endoftext|>/*
Given an integer. return a vector that has the number of even and odd digits respectively.

 Example:
    even_odd_count(-12) ==> {1, 1}
    even_odd_count(123) ==> {1, 2}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <string>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > even_odd_count(int num) {
   
    vector < int > even;
    vector < int > odd;
    int count = 0;
    
    while (num > 0) {
        
        if (num % 2 == 0) {
            even.push_back(count);
            count++;
        }
        else {
            odd.push_back(count);
            count++;
        }
        
        num = num / 2;
    }
    
    return even;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a positive integer, obtain its roman numeral equivalent as a string,
and return it in lowercase.
Restrictions: 1 <= num <= 1000

Examples:
>>> int_to_mini_roman(19) == "xix"
>>> int_to_mini_roman(152) == "clii"
>>> int_to_mini_roman(426) == "cdxxvi"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
string int_to_mini_romank(int number) {
    string current = "";
    vector < string > rep = {
        "m", "cm", "d", "cd", "c", "xc", "l", "xl", "x", "ix", "v", "iv", "i"}
    ;
    vector < int > num = {
        1000, 900, 500, 400, 100, 90, 50, 40, 10, 9, 5, 4, 1}
    ;
    int bt2 = 0;
    while (number > 0)
   
    {
        bt2 = number % 10;
        number /= 10;
        if (bt2 == 1)
        {
            current += rep[num[bt2]];
        }
        else
        {
            current += rep[bt2];
        }
    }
    return current;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that start with a given prefix.
>>> filter_by_prefix({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_prefix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_prefix(vector < string > strings, string prefix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(0, prefix.size()) == prefix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that end with a given suffix.
>>> filter_by_suffix({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_suffix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_suffix(vector < string > strings, string suffix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(s.size() - suffix.size(), suffix.size()) == suffix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain a given substring.
>>> filter_by_substring({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring(vector < string > strings, string substring) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.find(substring)!= string::npos) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain a given substring in a given order.
>>> filter_by_substring_order({}, "a", "b")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring_order({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a", "b")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring_order(vector < string > strings, string substring_a, string substring_b) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.find(substring_a)!= string::npos && s.find(substring_b)!= string::npos) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain a given substring in a given order.
>>> filter_by_substring_order_reverse({}, "a", "b")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring_order_reverse({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a", "b")
{"vector", "cde", "bcd", "abc"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring_order_reverse(vector < string > strings, string substring_a, string substring_b) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.find(substring_a)!= string::npos && s.find(substring_b)!= string::npos) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

using namespace std;
double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
double SK7 = 0;
double value;
value = poly(xs, SK7);
while (abs(value) > 1e-6)
 {
    double driv = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i < xs.size(); i++)
     {
       
       driv += xs[i] * pow(x, i);
     }
     SK7 = driv / value;
     value = poly(xs, SK7);
 }
return SK7;
}

Return maximum element in the vector.
>>> max_element({1, 2, 3})
3
>>> max_element({5, 3, -5, 2, -3, 3, 9, 0, 123, 1, -10})
123
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
float max_element(vector < float > l) {
   
   float max = l[0];
   for (int i = 1; i < l.size(); i++) {
      if (l[i] > max) {
         max = l[i];
      }
   }
   return max;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
prime_fib returns n-th number that is a Fibonacci number and it's also prime.
>>> prime_fib(1)
2
>>> prime_fib(2)
3
>>> prime_fib(3)
5
>>> prime_fib(4)
13
>>> prime_fib(5)
89
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int prime_fib(int n) {
    int Xt, f2, m;
    Xt = 1; f2 = 2;
    int count = 0;
    while (count < n)
     {
        Xt = Xt + f2;
        m = Xt; Xt = f2; f2 = m;
       
        if (Xt % 2 == 0)
        {
            count++;
        }
    }
    return Xt;
}

bool pairs_sum_to_zero(vector < int > l) {

<|endoftext|>/*
Checks if given string is a palindrome
>>> is_palindrome("")
true
>>> is_palindrome("aba")
true
>>> is_palindrome("aaaaa")

>>> is_palindrome("zbcd")

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool is_palindrome(string s)
{
    int len = s.length();
    int mid = len / 2;
    bool flag = true;
    for (int i = 0; i < mid; i++)
    {
        if (s[i]!= s[len - 1 - i])
        {
            flag = false;
            break;
        }
    }
    return flag;
}

/*
Checks if given string is a palindrome using recursion
>>> is_palindrome_recursive("")

>>> is_palindrome_recursive("aba")
true
>>> is_palindrome_recursive("aaaaa")
true
>>> is_palindrome_recursive("zbcd")
false
*/
bool is_palindrome_recursive(string s)
{
    if (s.length() <= 1)
    {
        return true;
    }
    if (s[0]!= s[s.length() - 1])
    {
        return false;
    }
    return is_palindrome_recursive(s.substr(1, s.length() - 1));
}

<|endoftext|>/*
remove_vowels is a function that takes string and returns string without vowels.
>>> remove_vowels("")
""
>>> remove_vowels("abcdef\nghijklm")
"bcdf\nghjklm"
>>> remove_vowels("abcdef")
"bcdf"
>>> remove_vowels("aaaaa")
""
>>> remove_vowels("aaBAA")
"B"
>>> remove_vowels("zbcd")
"zbcd"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <algorithm>
using std;
string remove_vowels(string text) {
    string out = "";
   
    for(int i = 0; i < text.length(); i++) {
        if(text[i]!= 'a' && text[i]!= 'e' && text[i]!= 'i' && text[i]!= 'o' && text[i]!= 'u')
            out += text[i];
    }
    return out;
}

}

<|endoftext|>/*
brackets is a string of '(' and ')'.
return true if every opening bracket has a corresponding closing bracket.

>>> correct_bracketing("(")
false
>>> correct_bracketing("()")
true
>>> correct_bracketing("(()())")
true
>>> correct_bracketing(")(()")
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool correct_bracketing(string brackets) {
    int level = 0;
    for (int z = 0; z < brackets.length(); z++)
     {
       
        if (brackets[z] == '(')
        {
            level++;
        }
        else if (brackets[z] == ')')
        {
            level--;
        }
        if (level == 0)
        {
            return false;
        }
    }
    return true;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
xs represent coefficients of a polynomial.
xs{0} + xs{1} * x + xs{2} * x^2 +....
 Return derivative of this polynomial in the same form.
>>> derivative({3, 1, 2, 4, 5})
{1, 4, 12, 20}
>>> derivative({1, 2, 3})
{2, 6}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < float > derivative(vector < float > xs) {
   
   vector < float > derivative;
   float x = xs[0];
   float y = xs[1];
   float z = xs[2];
   float d = 1;
   
   for (int i = 0; i < xs.size() - 1; i++) {
      
      float xi = xs[i];
      float yi = ys[i];
      float zi = zs[i];
      
      float dd = d * xi;
      float dy = d * yi;
      float dz = d * zi;
      
      derivative.push_back(dd + dy + dz);
      
      d *= x;
      
   }
   
   return derivative;
}

Write a function vowels_count which takes a string representing a word as input and returns the number of vowels in the string. Vowels in this case are 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u'. 
Here, 'y' is also a vowel, but only when it is at the end of the given word.
Example: 
>>> vowels_count("abcde") 
2 
>>> vowels_count("ACEDY") 
3
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <algorithm>
using std;
int vowels_count(string E) {
    string vowels = "aeiouAEIOU";
   
    int count = 0;
    
    for (int i = 0; i < E.size(); i++) {
        if (vowels.find(E[i])!= string::npos) {
            count++;
        }
    }
    
    return count;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain given substring
>>> filter_by_substring({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring({"abc", "bacd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "bacd", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring(vector < string > strings, string substring) {
    vector < string > out;
   
    for (auto &s: strings) {
        if (s.find(substring)!= string::npos) {
            out.push_back(s);
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/* Write a function that returns true if the object q will fly, and false otherwise. Example: will_it_fly({1, 2}, 5) false // 1+2 is less than the maximum possible weight, but it's unbalanced. will_it_fly({3, 2, 3}, 1) false // it's balanced, but 3+2+3 is more than the maximum possible weight. will_it_fly({3, 2, 3}, 9) true // 3+2+3 is less than the maximum possible weight, and it's balanced. will_it_fly({3}, 5) true // 3 is less than the maximum possible weight, and it's balanced. */ #include #include using std; bool will_it_fly(vector < int > q, int w) { int sum = 0; for (int J = 0; J < q.size(); J++) sum += q[J]; if (sum < w) return false; else return true; } int main() { vector < int > q; int w; scanf("%d %d", &w, &q); bool result = will_it_fly(q, w); printf("%d", result); } <|/ a dscore=0 |> <| c |> Please don't post only code as answer, but also provide an explanation what your code does and how it solves the problem of the question. string decimal_to_binary(int decimal) {

}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function that takes a string and returns true if the string
length is a prime number or false otherwise
Examples
prime_length("Hello") == true
prime_length("abcdcba") == true
prime_length("kittens") == true
prime_length("orange") == false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool prime_length(string str) {
    int l, Z;
   
    l = str.length();
    Z = l / 2;
    
    for (int i = 2; i <= l; i++) {
        if (str.length() % i == 0) {
            return false;
        }
    }
    return true;
}

Given a non-empty vector of integers lst. add the even elements that are at odd indices..


Examples:
    add({4, 2, 6, 7}) ==> 2 
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
int add(vector < int > lst) {
   
    int sum = 0;
    for (int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++) {
        if (i % 2 == 0) {
            sum += lst[i];
        }
    }
    return sum;
}

You are given a 2 dimensional data, as a nested vectors,
which is similar to matrix, however, unlike matrices,
each row may contain a different number of columns.
Given lst, and integer x, find integers x in the vector,
and return vector of vectors, {{x1, y1}, {x2, y2}...} such that
each vector is a coordinate - {row, columns}, starting with 0.
Sort coordinates initially by rows in ascending order.
Also, sort coordinates of the row by columns in descending order.

Examples:
get_row({
  {1,2,3,4,5,6},
  {1,2,3,4,1,6},
  {1,2,3,4,5,1}
}, 1) == {{0, 0}, {1, 4}, {1, 0}, {2, 5}, {2, 0}}
get_row({}, 1) == {}
get_row({{}, {1}, {1, 2, 3}}, 3) == {{2, 2}}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < vector < int > > get_row(vector < vector < int > > lst, int x) {
  vector < vector < int > > out = {
    }
  ;
 
  for (int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++) {
    for (int j = 0; j < lst[i].size(); j++) {
      if (lst[i][j] == x) {
        out.push_back({i, j});
      }
    }
  }
  
  sort(out.begin(), out.end(), [](const vector < int > &a, const vector < int > &b) -> bool {
    return a[0] > b[0];
  });
  
  sort(out.begin(), out.end(), [](const vector < int > &a, const vector < int > &b) -> bool {
    return a[1] > b[1];
  });
  
  return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function encrypt that takes a string as an argument and
returns a string encrypted with the alphabet being rotated. 
The alphabet should be rotated in a manner such that the letters 
shift down by two multiplied to two places.
For example:
encrypt("hi") returns "lm"
encrypt("asdfghjkl") returns "ewhjklnop"
encrypt("gf") returns "kj"
encrypt("et") returns "ix"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
string encrypt(string s) {
    string m75;
    int i;
   
    for(i = 0; i<s.length(); i++) {
        m75.push_back(s[i]);
    }
    
    for(i = 0; i<s.length(); i++) {
        m75[i] = m75[i] - 'a' + 2;
    }
    
    for(i = 0; i<s.length(); i++) {
        m75[i] = m75[i] + 'a';
    }
    
    return m75;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function that takes 3 numbers.
Returns true if one of the numbers is equal to the sum of the other two, and all numbers are integers.
Returns false in any other cases.

Examples
any_int(5, 2, 7)  true

any_int(3, 2, 2)  false

any_int(3, -2, 1)  true

any_int(3.6, -2.2, 2)  false



*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
using std;
bool any_int(float a, float r, float c) {
    if (round(a)!= a) return false;
   
    if (round(r)!= r) return false;
   
    if (round(c)!= c) return false;
   
    if (round(a+r+c)!= a+r+c) return false;
   
    return true;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a map, return true if all keys are strings in lower 
case or all keys are strings in upper case, else return false.
The function should return false is the given map is empty.
Examples:
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"b","banana"}}) should return true.
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"A","banana"}, {"B","banana"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"8","banana"}, {"a","apple"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"Name","John"}, {"Age","36"}, {"City","Houston"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"STATE","NC"}, {"ZIP","12345"} }) should return true.
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <map>
using std;
bool check_dict_case(map < string, string > dict) {
    map < string, string > :: iterator it;
    int islower = 0, isupper = 0;
    if (dict.size() == 0) return false;
    for (it = dict.begin(); it!= dict.end(); it++)
     {
        string key = it -> first;
       
        if (islower(key) == true)
        {
            islower++;
        }
        else
        {
            isupper++;
        }
    }
    if (islower == dict.size() && isupper == dict.size()) return true;
    return false;
}
